{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12270,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cercocarpus betuloides, commonly known as Mountain Mahogany, is a drought-tolerant plant once established. During the first growing season, regular watering helps to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it requires minimal watering, typically only during prolonged periods of drought. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases. Ensuring good drainage is crucial to prevent waterlogging, especially in areas with frequent rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cercocarpus betuloides thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat and prevent leaf scorch. In cooler regions, it can handle more direct sunlight without issue. Planting in a location with some protection from harsh afternoon sun is particularly important in dry regions to prevent drought stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cercocarpus betuloides is best done during the late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. The primary goal of pruning is to maintain shape and remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth. Light pruning is usually sufficient. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. Pruning helps to maintain an open canopy, which improves air circulation and reduces the risk of disease. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and to prevent the spread of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Birchleaf Mountain Mahogany","description":"Cercocarpus betuloides is a shrub or small tree in the rose family. Its common names include mountain mahogany and birch leaf mountain mahogany The common name \"mahogany\" comes from the hardness and color of the wood, although the genus is not a true mahogany.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["Birchleaf Mountain Mahogany"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Cercocarpus betuloides"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13967,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anacamptis pyramidalis, or the pyramidal orchid, prefers well-drained soil and typically does not require frequent watering in natural settings. Ensure the soil is slightly moist but never waterlogged, especially if growing in a pot. During prolonged dry periods, especially in the plant's active growing season in spring, you may need to water occasionally. Reduce watering during the plant's dormant period in late summer and autumn to prevent the bulb from rotting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anacamptis pyramidalis thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. If grown in full sun, ensure it has good soil moisture to prevent drying out, as this orchid species can be sensitive to prolonged drought. In partial shade, especially in hotter regions, plants are often healthier and may even produce more vibrant blooms. Like many orchids, avoid deep shade, as it can lead to weak growth and poor flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anacamptis pyramidalis is mostly about managing dead or spent plant material. After the flowers have faded in late summer, allow the foliage to die back naturally—it provides nourishment to the bulbs for the next growing season. Only remove any truly dead or decaying parts to prevent disease. No heavy pruning is needed, as the plant is typically left to its own natural growth cycle. Avoid cutting back green leaves or stems during the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pyramidal orchid","description":"Anacamptis pyramidalis, the pyramidal orchid, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the genus Anacamptis of the family Orchidaceae. The scientific name Anacamptis derives from Greek ανακάμτειν 'anakamptein' meaning 'bend forward', while the Latin name pyramidalis refers to the pyramidal form of the inflorescence.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["pyramidal orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Anacamptis pyramidalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Chalky","Calcareous"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13868,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dryopteris campyloptera, commonly known as the Mountain Wood Fern, prefers consistently moist but not soggy soil. Ensure the soil is well-drained and water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells. Avoid letting the soil completely dry out between waterings, as this can stress the fern. It’s essential to maintain a balance; too much water can lead to root rot, while too little can cause the fronds to wilt and dry out. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryopteris campyloptera thrives in partial to full shade conditions. It is naturally found under forest canopies where it receives indirect light; hence, replicating these conditions will promote optimal growth. Avoid exposing the fern to direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, as this can scorch the delicate fronds. If grown indoors, placing it in a north or east-facing window can provide the appropriate amount of light. Ensure the plant gets moderate light to maintain lush, green foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dryopteris campyloptera involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and improve overall appearance. This can be done at any time of the year. In early spring, before new growth begins, tidy up the plant by cutting back the old foliage near the base. This not only promotes new frond production but also helps reduce the risk of diseases. Regular cleaning of fallen leaves and debris around the plant can further prevent pest infestations and fungal issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mountain wood fern","description":"Dryopteris campyloptera, also known as the mountain wood fern, is a large American fern of higher elevations and latitudes. It was formerly known as Dryopteris spinulosa var. americana. This species also has been mistakenly referred to D. austriaca and D. dilatata.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["mountain wood fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dryopteris campyloptera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be careful not to prune too heavily, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Nuttall's Snapdragon","description":"Antirrhinum nuttallianum (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12672,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ambrosia ambrosioides, commonly known as canyon ragweed, prefers a well-drained soil and thrives in dry conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's best to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. During its active growing season in spring and summer, water deeply but infrequently, approximately once every two weeks, depending on your climate and soil type. Reduce watering significantly in fall and winter as the plant's growth slows. Always check the top inch of soil and ensure it's dry before watering again to avoid overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ambrosia ambrosioides flourishes best in full sun, which means it needs at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sunlight will ensure optimal growth and health. It is quite adaptable to various light conditions but might become leggy if it doesn't get enough sunlight. Plant it in a location where it receives ample light throughout the day, and consider protecting it from harsh afternoon sun in very hot climates. Monitor the plant's response to light and adjust its location if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ambrosia ambrosioides is generally minimal, but occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Prune dead or damaged branches any time of year to promote healthy growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, you can prune it back in late winter or early spring before the new growth season begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears and make cuts just above a node to encourage new growth from that point. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Big Bursage","description":"Ambrosia ambrosioides, also known as canyon ragweed or chicura is a ragweed found in the deserts of northern Mexico (Baja California, Baja California Sur, Chihuahua, Durango, Sonora), Arizona, and California (Ventura + San Diego Counties).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Big Bursage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ambrosia ambrosioides"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13371,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Olneya tesota, commonly known as the Desert Ironwood, is highly drought-tolerant, requiring minimal watering. In its natural habitat, it thrives with little to no supplemental water, enduring long dry spells. For cultivated plants, water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings, typically every 2-3 weeks. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure any excess moisture drains away efficiently. During its first year of growth, water more frequently to establish deep roots, tapering off as the plant matures. Always adjust watering based on local rainfall and climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Olneya tesota thrives in full sunlight, reflecting its desert origins. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow robustly. The plant can withstand intense desert sunlight and high temperatures, making it suitable for arid landscapes. When planting Olneya tesota, choose a location with plenty of direct, unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. Insufficient light may lead to poor growth or a spindly appearance. While adaptable to some partial shade, optimal conditions mirror its native desert environment, ensuring healthy development and vibrant blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Olneya tesota is generally minimal, focusing on maintaining its natural shape and removing any dead or damaged wood. Ideally, prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing reduces stress on the plant and prevents exposure to pests. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts smooth and infection-free. Trim selectively to enhance the structure and open up the canopy, improving air circulation. Avoid over-pruning as it can stunt the plant's growth and reduce its natural beauty. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12968,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Delphinium cardinale, commonly known as the scarlet larkspur, requires regular watering, especially during its active growing season in the spring and early summer. The soil should remain consistently moist, but not waterlogged, to prevent root rot. It is crucial to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings, especially as the plant enters its dormant phase in late summer or fall. During its dormant period, reduce watering significantly. Always ensure good drainage for the plant to thrive and avoid overhead watering to minimize the risk of fungal diseases affecting the foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Delphinium cardinale thrives best in full sun environments. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to encourage strong, rapid growth and vibrant blooms. In regions with extremely hot climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching, but it is generally well adapted to high light conditions. Ensure the plant is positioned where it won't be overshadowed by taller plants or structures, as insufficient sunlight can lead to weak stems and a reduced flowering display. Adequate sunlight is crucial for maximizing the plant's striking scarlet flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Delphinium cardinale is essential to promote healthy growth and flowering. After the plant finishes its blooming period, typically in late summer, deadhead the faded flowers to encourage a potential second bloom and prevent self-seeding. In the fall, cut back the stems to ground level after the plant has completely died back. This helps prevent mold and pests over winter. In early spring, remove any debris or dead stems around the emerging shoots to promote healthy new growth. Regularly check for and remove dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scarlet Larkspur","description":"Delphinium cardinale is a species of larkspur known by the common names scarlet larkspur and cardinal larkspur. This wildflower is native to California and Baja California, where it grows on coastal, inland, and desert chaparral slopes, such as the Colorado Desert, and the Peninsular and Transverse Ranges. The presence of diterpenoid alkaloids, probably including the highly toxic methyllycaconitine, in the above-ground parts of D. cardinale plants means that they are likely to be toxic.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California"],"other_name":["Scarlet Larkspur"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew","Slug","Snail"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Delphinium cardinale"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be cautious not to overwater, as it prefers well-drained soils and can suffer in overly moist conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cercocarpus minutiflorus thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its health and vigor. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure supports the best growth and flowering. This sunlight preference aligns with its native habitat in sunny, arid, and rugged terrains. When positioning this plant in your garden or landscape, choose an area that receives abundant sunlight throughout the day. Sufficient sunlight ensures robust growth, enhances blooming, and promotes a resilient structure, helping it withstand outdoor conditions and environmental stresses effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cercocarpus minutiflorus should be done minimally and primarily for maintaining shape and removing any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring while the plant is still dormant. Use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the wood. If shaping is required, prune selectively to thin out dense growth, allowing sunlight and air to penetrate the canopy, enhancing overall plant health. Avoid heavy pruning as this plant maintains its form naturally and excessive cutting can stress the plant. Additionally, you can tidy up the plant by removing older, browning leaves throughout the growing season. As ornamental grasses go dormant over winter, refrain from heavy pruning during this time to avoid stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Smilo Grass","description":"Piptatherum miliaceum is a species of grass known by the common name smilograss. Remove any dead or damaged fronds to maintain a tidy appearance. This can be done at any time of year. Be cautious when pruning, as the \"saw\" in saw palmetto refers to the sharp, serrated edges of the petioles, which can cause injury. Wearing gloves and using sharp, clean pruning tools can aid in safely removing fronds and avoiding damage to the plant or yourself."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"saw palmetto","description":"Serenoa repens, commonly known as saw palmetto, is the sole species currently classified in the genus Serenoa. It is drought-tolerant but thrives best with regular watering during its growth period, particularly in spring and early summer. However, it's crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as the plant dislikes overly moist conditions. During its dormant phase in late summer and fall, drastically reduce watering to maintain just enough moisture to keep the soil from becoming completely dry. Adjust watering frequency based on environmental conditions, ensuring the plant is neither starved of water nor waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Olsynium douglasii thrives in full sun to part shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, provide the plant with several hours of direct sunlight each day. This sun loving plant is adaptable to varying light conditions but performs best with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. If planted in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from drying out too quickly. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may result in less vigorous growth and reduced blooming. Choose a planting site that receives ample sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Olsynium douglasii is relatively straightforward due to its grass-like stems and minimal maintenance needs. After the flowering season, you can deadhead by removing spent blooms to promote tidiness and potentially extend the blooming period. Cut the flower stalks back to the base as they fade. In late summer, you can trim away any foliage that appears damaged or unsightly, but it is generally best to let the plant die back naturally, as this helps it accumulate energy for the following growing season. Always use clean, sharp tools when pruning to prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"grasswidow","description":"Olsynium douglasii (syn. Sisyrinchium douglasii, Sisyrinchium grandiflorum) is a flowering plant, commonly known as Douglas' olsynium, Douglas' grasswidow, grasswidow, blue-eyed grass, purple-eyed-grass, or satin flower, in the genus Olsynium, native to western North America from southern British Columbia south to northern California, and east to northwest Utah. It is the only species in the genus Olsynium in North America, the remaining 11 species being from South America. It was formerly treated in the related genus Sisyrinchium.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["grasswidow"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Olsynium douglasii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12470,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Baileya multiradiata, commonly known as desert marigold, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. It is important to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so infrequent watering is best. During hot summer months, water deeply but less often to promote deeper root growth. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant is dormant. Always use well-draining soil to ensure excess water can escape easily."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baileya multiradiata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day. This plant is native to desert regions and is well-adapted to bright, arid conditions. If grown in partial shade, it may exhibit reduced flowering and leggy, sparse growth. Make sure to choose a location with ample sunlight exposure, preferably one that mimics its natural desert habitat, which will help the plant maintain its vibrant color and prolific blooming cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Baileya multiradiata is relatively straightforward and primarily involves removing spent blooms to encourage more flowering and prevent the plant from going to seed too quickly. In addition, occasionally trim back any dead or damaged stems to maintain a tidy appearance and promote healthy growth. It's best to prune in the cooler months of early spring or fall. When trimming, use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant and always cut just above a set of leaves or a leaf node."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Desert Marigold","description":"Baileya multiradiata is a North American species of sun-loving wildflowers native to the deserts of northern Mexico and the Southwestern United States. It has been found in the States of Sonora, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Durango, Aguascalientes, California, Arizona, Nevada, Utah, New Mexico, and Texas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Desert Marigold"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Baileya multiradiata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13772,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Potentilla canadensis, commonly known as the dwarf cinquefoil, prefers moderate watering. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in fall and winter as the plant enters dormancy. Ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. It's also beneficial to allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided, as this can lead to waterlogged roots and poor plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, Potentilla canadensis should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, it can benefit from a bit of afternoon shade to protect it from the intense sun. However, too much shade may inhibit blooming and lead to leggy growth. If placed in an area with morning sun and afternoon shade, the plant will perform well without getting scorched by the midday sun. Select a planting site accordingly to ensure robust health and vibrant flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Potentilla canadensis is primarily done to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth. Prune in early spring before new growth starts, by cutting back any dead or damaged stems. Throughout the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to promote continued blooming. You can also trim back any leggy or overgrown stems to maintain a compact appearance. Avoid severe pruning as it can stress the plant, resulting in fewer blooms. Regular, light pruning will invigorate the plant, encouraging denser foliage and a more prolific blooming season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"dwarf cinquefoil","description":"Potentilla canadensis, the dwarf cinquefoil, is a species of cinquefoil (genus Potentilla) native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["dwarf cinquefoil"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Potentilla canadensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growth phase in spring, you may water it moderately to encourage growth, but be cautious of over-watering, which can lead to root rot. Once the flowering period ends, reduce watering to allow the plant to go dormant. A good rule of thumb is to water only when the soil has thoroughly dried out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lomatium nudicaule prefers full sun to partial shade, thriving best in environments that mimic its natural temperate grassland and open woodland habitats. For optimal growth, position the plant where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. If you're planting in a shaded area, consider choosing a spot that allows morning sun and afternoon shade to balance light exposure without overheating."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lomatium nudicaule is generally minimal. It's best to allow the plant to grow naturally without much interference to maintain its natural form. However, removing dead or damaged foliage and flower stalks after the blooming season can help improve its overall appearance and encourage healthy growth the following year. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant. If necessary, prune in late summer after flowering has ceased, ensuring you use clean and sharp tools to prevent any potential disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Barestem Biscuitroot","description":"Lomatium nudicaule is a species of flowering plant in the carrot family known by the common names pestle lomatium,:110 barestem biscuitroot, Indian celery and Indian consumption plant. It is a perennial herb growing up to about 70 centimeters tall from a thick taproot. While it can tolerate some morning sun, midday and afternoon sun can be too intense, especially in hotter climates, leading to leaf scorching. In its natural habitat, it is commonly found in forest understories. Aim to plant it in an area that receives dappled sunlight throughout the day. Too much direct sunlight can stress the plant, while full shade can hinder its flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viburnum acerifolium is best done in late winter or early spring, just before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first to maintain plant health. To shape or control the size of the plant, prune selectively, cutting back to a bud or lateral branch that is facing the desired direction of growth. Thinning out crowded areas can improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid excessive pruning as it may reduce flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12373,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gloeophyllum sepiarium, commonly known as the \"brown rot fungus,\" does not require traditional watering as it is a fungus found on decaying wood, particularly conifers. It derives its moisture from the wood it inhabits. If cultivating in a lab or simulated environment for study, maintaining a controlled humidity level consistent with its natural habitat is crucial. Ensure that the wood it grows on remains slightly damp but not overly wet, as excessive moisture can promote unwanted competing mold growths and could be detrimental to the fungus' development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gloeophyllum sepiarium does not require sunlight for its growth as it is a fungus relying on organic matter, specifically wood, for nourishment. It is often found in shaded forested areas where decaying conifer wood is abundant. If studying or cultivating Gloeophyllum sepiarium, ensure the environmental setup mimics its natural conditions, which implies low light to dark conditions. Direct exposure to sunlight is unnecessary and could potentially dry out the substrate it relies on for nutrients, thus should be avoided in controlled settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Gloeophyllum sepiarium as it is a fungus rather than a plant. In a laboratory setting, you might \"harvest\" or remove portions for study. When doing so, ensure that removal is done carefully to avoid damaging the structure of the remaining fungus. Clean-cutting tools to prevent contamination, and managing the host substrate to control growth and maintain fungus health are key. Fungal fruiting bodies naturally decompose, and manual removal in a non-controlled environment isn't typically done."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Conifer Mazegill","description":"Gloeophyllum sepiarium (Rusty gilled polypore) is a wood decay fungus that causes a brown rot. Gloeophyllum sepiarium grows in thin, dark brown/green brackets on dead conifers. Often found on wood in lumberyards, the fruiting body grows for only one year, and produces spores in late summer and autumn. Its hymenial surface is distinctive from other polypores due to the presence of gills. Gloeophyllum sepiarium is inedible.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Conifer Mazegill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gloeophyllum sepiarium"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13175,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrilla verticillata thrives in a fully aquatic environment. As an aquatic plant, it requires a consistent supply of fresh, clean water to support its growth. Proper water circulation is essential to distribute nutrients and prevent stagnation. In controlled environments like aquariums, ensure that the water is at an appropriate pH level, preferably between 6.5 and 7.5, and maintain a moderate hardness. Regular water changes can help control nutrient levels and limit algae growth, which can sometimes compete with Hydrilla for resources."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydrilla verticillata requires moderate to high light conditions to flourish, as light is vital for its photosynthesis process. In aquariums or ponds, provide around 8 to 12 hours of light daily. Natural sunlight is beneficial if the plant is in an outdoor setting, but in indoor environments, supplement with full spectrum aquarium lights to imitate natural conditions. Ensure the plant receives enough light without exposure to intense, direct midday sun, which can potentially encourage algae growth, thereby outcompeting the Hydrilla for available resources."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrilla verticillata is essential to control its rapid growth and prevent it from taking over aquatic environments. Regularly trim the stems to manage its height and spread, especially if it is used in aquariums or controlled tanks. Removing excess growth will prevent it from blocking light to other plants and maintain balanced oxygen levels in the water. It's advisable to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to ensure clean cuts, which promotes healthier regrowth. Additionally, removing any damaged or decaying parts can prevent them from deteriorating water quality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hydrilla","description":"Hydrilla (waterthyme) is a genus of aquatic plant, usually treated as containing just one species, Hydrilla verticillata, though some botanists divide it into several species. It is essential to maintain consistently moist soil, especially during the first few years after planting, to help the tree establish a deep root system. Water deeply once or twice a week during dry periods, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering should be avoided as soggy conditions can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature fluctuations, benefit the overall health of the tree."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Picea breweriana thrives in full sun to partial shade. However, for optimal growth, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more sun, while in hotter regions, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent heat stress. It is adaptable but performs best in cooler, moist environments, reflecting its native habitat in the mountains of southwestern Oregon. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures robust growth and maintains the tree’s characteristic graceful form and foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Picea breweriana should be done with care, primarily to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the tree; instead, focus on light shaping if necessary. When pruning, make clean cuts close to the branch collar to promote proper healing. Regular inspection for any signs of disease or pests can aid in maintaining the tree’s overall health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brewer's spruce","description":"Picea breweriana, known as Brewer spruce, Brewer's weeping spruce, or weeping spruce, is a species of spruce native to western North America, where it is one of the rarest on the continent, endemic to the Klamath Mountains of southwest Oregon and northwest California. The specific epithet breweriana is in honor of the American botanist William Henry Brewer.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Brewer's spruce"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spruce aphid"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Picea breweriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant, focusing instead on gently tidying up as necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"crested wood fern","description":"Dryopteris cristata is a species of fern native to wetlands throughout the Northern Hemisphere. If you're in a particularly hot climate, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the delicate flowers from scorching while still ensuring the plant receives ample morning sunlight. The roots of Clematis prefer to be shaded and cool, so consider adding mulch or planting low ground cover plants at the base to help regulate soil temperature and moisture."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Clematis foetida in early spring before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so cutting back the previous year's growth encourages bushier growth and more flowers. Remove dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health. Trim back to a pair of healthy buds—typically 12-18 inches from the base. Regular pruning also helps control the size and shape of this vigorous climber. Throughout the growing season, promptly remove spent blooms to encourage continued flowering and prevent the plant from setting unnecessary seed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellowish-Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Clematis foetida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

Remember to dispose of any pruned material properly to prevent the spread of pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"false nettle","description":"Boehmeria cylindrica, with common names false nettle and bog hemp, is a herb in the family Urticaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12774,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Boerhavia coccinea, commonly known as Scarlet Spiderling or Red Spiderling, is a drought-tolerant plant, which means it requires minimal watering. It is best to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, as it can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant moderately, but significantly reduce watering in winter when its growth slows down. Ensure the pot or ground soil has adequate drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots. Over time, pay attention to the plant’s growth and adjust the watering frequency according to its specific needs in your environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Boerhavia coccinea thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, place the plant in a location that receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If you live in a region with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. In areas with lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. By ensuring adequate sunlight, you can encourage a bushier plant with vivid flowers throughout its blooming season. Adjust the planting location as needed to match these light requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Boerhavia coccinea can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. To prune, use sharp, clean scissors or pruners to remove any dead or damaged stems, which helps improve the overall appearance and health of the plant. It's best to prune in early spring before the main growing season begins or after flowering to promote new growth. Regularly trimming the plant can help control its size if it starts to spread too aggressively. When pruning, avoid removing more than one-third of the plant at once to ensure it remains healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"scarlet spiderling","description":"Boerhavia coccinea is a species of flowering plant in the four o'clock family which is known by many common names, including scarlet spiderling, red boerhavia, hogweed, and in Spanish, hierba del cancer and hierba de la hormiga.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico","Central America","South America","India"],"other_name":["scarlet spiderling"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Boerhavia coccinea"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13176,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrophyllum capitatum, commonly known as ballhead waterleaf, prefers evenly moist soil conditions. However, ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. In natural settings, it thrives in damp, shady areas, so mimicking these conditions in a garden or container will promote healthy growth. Avoid letting the plant sit in excess water by providing adequate drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydrophyllum capitatum thrives in a shady or partially shady environment, as it is naturally found in forested or woodland areas. Providing it with filtered sunlight or partial shade will mimic its natural habitat, helping it flourish. Avoid exposing the plant to harsh, direct sunlight, especially during the peak hours of the day, as it can lead to leaf scorch and stress the plant. Ideal locations may include the north or east side of a house, or under a canopy of trees that allow dappled sunlight to reach the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrophyllum capitatum is minimal as it is a low-growing perennial and naturally maintains a tidy appearance. However, deadheading or removing spent flowers can help encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if not desired. Additionally, lightly trimming any damaged or diseased leaves can help keep the plant healthy. If the plant becomes too dense, a gentle thinning can improve air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal issues. Conduct any pruning in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ballhead waterleaf","description":"Hydrophyllum capitatum, is a species of waterleaf known by the common name ballhead waterleaf. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13374,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Onopordum acanthium, commonly known as Scotch thistle, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers well-drained soil. It's important not to overwater this plant as it can tolerate dry conditions better than excessive moisture. Water the plant moderately during its active growth period, but allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions. During its dormant season, reduce watering significantly as it requires minimal moisture. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other related issues, especially in poorly drained soils. Monitoring the soil's dryness is crucial to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Onopordum acanthium thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sun exposure per day to flourish. When choosing a planting location, select an area that receives abundant sunlight, as insufficient light can result in weak, leggy growth. This plant is well-suited to open, sunny areas and can tolerate the heat of direct sunlight, making it an excellent choice for sunny gardens or landscapes. Ensuring adequate sunlight will support strong stems and vibrant flowering, enhancing the plant's ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not necessarily a primary requirement for Onopordum acanthium, but it can be pruned to manage its size and prevent it from becoming unruly. If pruning is desired, it should be conducted after the flowering phase. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage new growth and prevent self-seeding, which can make the plant invasive. Remove the dead or damaged stems to improve the plant's vigor and overall appearance. Remember to wear gloves as the plant has spiny leaves and stems, which can be quite sharp and potentially cause injury."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cotton thistle","description":"Onopordum acanthium (cotton thistle, Scotch thistle) is a flowering plant in the family Asteraceae. It is native to Europe and Western Asia from the Iberian Peninsula east to Kazakhstan, and north to central Scandinavia, and widely naturalised elsewhere. It is a vigorous biennial plant with coarse, spiny leaves and conspicuous spiny-winged stems.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["cotton thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Onopordum acanthium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12874,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cestrum parqui, commonly known as Chilean Jessamine, prefers well-drained soil and does best if its watering needs are carefully managed. Water the plant thoroughly during its growing season in the spring and summer, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Over-watering can lead to root rot. In the fall and winter, reduce watering frequency to allow the soil to dry out slightly between watering. This helps mimic its natural dry season and encourages better flowering the following year. Always monitor the plant for signs of over- or under-watering, such as yellowing leaves or wilting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chilean Jessamine thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish and produce its fragrant blooms. While it can tolerate some partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the plant grows robustly and maintains its best shape and flowering potential. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, place it near a south- or west-facing window to provide adequate sunlight. Regularly rotating the plant ensures even growth and sun exposure on all sides."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cestrum parqui is essential for promoting bushier growth and better blooms. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. You can also prune back up to one-third of the previous year's growth to encourage a more compact and tidier shape. During the growing season, remove spent flowers (deadheading) to direct the plant’s energy towards new growth and reblooming. Wearing gloves while pruning is advised as the plant is toxic if ingested."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"green cestrum","description":"Cestrum parqui, commonly known as green cestrum or willow-leaved jessamine - and sometimes incorrectly referred to as \"mortal nightshade\" - is a species of flowering plant native to Chile.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Chile"],"other_name":["green cestrum"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cestrum parqui"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes first, cutting them back to the ground. Next, thin out the canes to allow good air circulation, selecting 6-8 healthy canes per plant and cutting the rest at the base. Regular pruning will also help control the plant’s spread and prevent it from becoming invasive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"elmleaf blackberry","description":"Rubus ulmifolius is a species of wild blackberry known by the English common name elmleaf blackberry or thornless blackberry and the Spanish common name zarzamora. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12274,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceanothus velutinus, commonly known as snowbrush, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During the first year after planting, water deeply and regularly to help the roots establish. Once established, water only during extended periods of drought, as overwatering can lead to root rot. To water effectively, ensure the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings. A layer of mulch can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. In heavy clay soil, take care to avoid water pooling by adjusting the watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ceanothus velutinus thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but flowering may be reduced, and the plant may become leggy. Ensure it receives ample morning sunlight, especially if grown in areas with hot afternoon sun, to prevent leaf scorch. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant. Proper sun exposure will support its growth habit and prolific display of flowers in the blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ceanothus velutinus is typically minimal, mainly focusing on maintaining its shape and removing any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any crossing branches that could rub against each other and create wounds, as well as any that detract from the plant's natural shape. Light trimming after flowering can encourage bushier growth and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts that promote healthy regrowth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Snowbrush Ceanothus","description":"Ceanothus velutinus, with the common names snowbrush ceanothus, red root, and tobacco brush, is a species of shrub in the family Rhamnaceae. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant every 2-4 weeks, allowing the soil to dry out fully between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has drainage holes. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency significantly as the cactus enters dormancy. It's better to underwater than overwater this drought-tolerant plant, so err on the side of caution when in doubt."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia chlorotica thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sun each day. This cactus is well-adapted to very bright environments and benefits from a sunny, south-facing window if grown indoors. During the hotter parts of the year, gradual acclimation to increased sun exposure can prevent sunburn on new growth. Outdoors, place the plant where it can receive ample sunlight. If limited, consider using grow lights to supplement its light needs. The intensity and duration of light directly impact its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia chlorotica is generally minimal and mainly involves removing dead or damaged pads. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid introducing diseases. If the cactus is overgrown or misshaped, you can trim back some pads to promote a more desirable growth pattern, but do so sparingly. Wear protective gloves as the pads have spines. Prune during the warmer part of the year to ensure quicker recovery of the plant. Pruned segments can be used for propagation if desired, but allow cuts to callus over a few days before replanting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pancake Pricklypear","description":"Opuntia chlorotica is a species of plant in the family Cactaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14061,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Magnolia tripetala, commonly known as the umbrella magnolia, prefers moist, well-drained soil. It is essential to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to maintain adequate soil moisture. However, while the tree needs consistent moisture, it is crucial to avoid waterlogging, which may harm the roots. A good practice is to water it deeply once a week, ensuring the water penetrates several inches into the soil. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering, particularly beneficial in hotter climates or during dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Magnolia tripetala thrives best in partial shade to full sun conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the leaves from scorching. When planting this magnolia, consider a location that offers morning sun and some dappled shade in the afternoon. This plant can also adapt to full sun if it has adequate water. The right balance of sunlight helps ensure robust growth and encourages prolific blooming, especially during its early flowering season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Magnolia tripetala should be minimal and primarily focused on maintaining its natural form. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, just before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage healthy growth. If necessary, thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation within the canopy. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree and diminish its flowering capacity. Magnolia tripetala usually requires only light maintenance pruning once it is established, allowing it to grow in its unique, umbrella-like shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"umbrella magnolia","description":"Magnolia tripetala, commonly called umbrella magnolia or simply umbrella-tree, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States in the Appalachian Mountains, the Ozarks, and the Ouachita Mountains. The name \"umbrella tree\" derives from the fact that the large leaves are clustered at the tips of the branches forming an umbrella-shaped structure.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["umbrella magnolia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Magnolia tripetala"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12473,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coleogyne ramosissima, commonly known as blackbrush, is a drought-tolerant plant commonly found in arid regions. It requires very little water and should never be overwatered, as too much moisture can lead to root rot. It's best to let the soil completely dry out between waterings. When you do water, ensure it is deep and thorough to encourage the roots to grow far into the soil, mimicking the natural rainfall it would receive in its desert habitat. During periods of rain, natural conditions usually suffice, and additional watering is not necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coleogyne ramosissima thrives best in full sunlight, which mimics its natural desert habitat. It should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and poor flowering. If growing indoors or in a less arid region, place the plant where it can receive maximum sunlight, such as on a south-facing window. If planting outdoors, choose an open area in the garden where there is no obstruction from larger plants or structures to ensure it receives adequate sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coleogyne ramosissima is generally not necessary as it grows into a naturally rounded and dense shape. However, if required, pruning can be done to maintain its shape and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth starts. When pruning, ensure to use clean and sharp tools to make smooth cuts, which help prevent the plant from becoming infected. Avoid excessive pruning since it can stress the plant, considering its slow-growing nature."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blackbrush","description":"Coleogyne ramosissima or blackbrush, is a low lying, dark grayish-green, aromatic, spiny, perennial, soft wooded shrub, native to the deserts of the southwestern United States. It is called blackbrush because the gray branches darken when wet by rains. It is in the rose family (Rosaceae), and is the only species in the monotypic genus Coleogyne.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["Blackbrush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Coleogyne ramosissima"],"soil":["Gravelly","Loamy","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13672,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Streptopus amplexifolius, commonly known as twisted stalk, prefers consistently moist soil conditions. It thrives in a natural woodland setting where the soil is rich in organic matter and retains moisture without becoming waterlogged. It’s important to ensure that the plant is kept evenly moist, particularly during the growing season. Water the plant more frequently in dry weather or if your climate is naturally less humid. However, be cautious not to overwater, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and mimic the plant's natural environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant prefers partial to full shade, replicating the dappled sunlight conditions of its native woodland habitats. Direct sunlight can be too intense and may scorch the leaves, so it is crucial to avoid placing the plant in areas where it will be exposed to full sun, especially during the hottest part of the day. An ideal location would be under the canopy of larger trees or shrubs that can provide filtered light throughout the day. If planted in a garden, a north or east-facing location is often suitable. Adjust light exposure according to observed plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Streptopus amplexifolius is usually minimal, as the plant maintains a neat and natural growth habit. The primary focus should be on removing any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth and improve plant appearance. This can be done in early spring before new growth begins or after the growing season has ended. For aesthetic purposes or to control size, any wayward stems can be trimmed back. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant and prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white twisted-stalk","description":"Streptopus amplexifolius (twistedstalk, clasping twistedstalk,claspleaf twistedstalk, white twisted-stalk, or watermelon berry) is a species of flowering plant in the family Liliaceae, native to North America, Europe and Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["white twisted-stalk"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Streptopus amplexifolius"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13775,"attracts":["Frogs"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrocharis morsus-ranae, commonly known as frogbit, is an aquatic plant that thrives in water. It doesn't require traditional watering like terrestrial plants since it grows on water surfaces. However, maintaining a consistent water level is crucial. Ensure the water is clean and balanced in nutrients, as water changes encourage healthy growth. The plant absorbs nutrients directly from water, so it's vital to monitor water quality. If grown in a pond or aquarium, keep it free from excessive algae growth. Avoid chlorinated water and check for proper filtration if in an artificial environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydrocharis morsus-ranae prefers partial to full sunlight to thrive. Ideally, provide it with about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, which mimics its natural environment. However, it can adapt to different lighting conditions and tolerate some shade. In an indoor setting or in aquariums, a grow light may substitute for natural sunlight, providing similar light intensity. Avoid placing it in locations with intense, scorching sun as this can cause stress and lead to leaf scorching. Ensure balanced exposure to light so the plant photosynthesizes efficiently without becoming overwhelmed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrocharis morsus-ranae involves removing dead or excessive leaves to prevent overcrowding in its aquatic environment. Regularly check for browning or decaying leaves and gently snip them off at the base using clean scissors. This encourages new growth and prevents the plant from blocking light to other aquatic plants. If growing aggressively, thin out some plants to maintain balance in shared spaces. Periodically clear accumulated debris among the plants, as this can lead to poor water quality and hinder growth. Regular pruning also helps maintain the aesthetic appeal of your water feature."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"European Frog-bit","description":"Hydrocharis morsus-ranae, frogbit, is a flowering plant belonging to the genus Hydrocharis in the family Hydrocharitaceae. In North America, it is referred to as common frogbit or European frog's-bit to distinguish it from the related American frogbit (Limnobium spongia).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["European Frog-bit"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hydrocharis morsus-ranae"],"soil":["Wet","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13472,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus balfouriana, or the Foxtail Pine, is a drought-tolerant tree once established. It naturally grows in arid, mountainous environments, so it requires minimal watering. In general, young trees should be watered regularly during the first growing season to help establish a deep, extensive root system. Thereafter, water should be reduced, and the tree's infrequent, deep watering should be suffice. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, and ensure good drainage to imitate its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus balfouriana thrives in full sun, which is crucial for its healthy growth and development. It naturally occurs in high-elevation areas with ample sunlight, and this should be mirrored in cultivation. Aim to provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. Inadequate light can stunt growth and reduce the tree's vigor. While it is adaptable to less than ideal light conditions, maximum sun exposure will enhance growth, resin production, and overall plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus balfouriana is minimal under typical circumstances. It should be conducted mainly to remove dead or diseased branches, which can occur during its dormancy period in late winter or early spring. This timing helps prevent disease transmission and allows for quick healing of cuts. Make clean cuts close to the branch collar, avoiding excessive cutting which could stress the tree. Pruning for shape is generally not necessary as the tree has a naturally attractive, symmetrical form. Light, selective pruning can manage growth and enhance overall appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"foxtail pine","description":"Pinus balfouriana (foxtail pine) is a rare high-elevation pine that is endemic to California, United States. It is closely related to the Great Basin and Rocky Mountain bristlecone pines, in the subsection Balfourianae. The two disjunct populations are found in the southern Klamath Mountains (subspecies balfouriana) and the southern Sierra Nevada (subspecies austrina). A small outlying population was reported in southern Oregon, but was proven to have been misidentified.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["foxtail pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus balfouriana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13872,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dryopteris intermedia, commonly known as the intermediate wood fern, prefers consistently moist but not soggy soil conditions. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells or prolonged periods of heat, to maintain even moisture levels around its roots. Although it can tolerate short dry periods, prolonged dryness may lead to frond browning. When watering, aim to thoroughly soak the soil, allowing excess water to drain away, as standing water can cause root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryopteris intermedia thrives in dappled or partial shade but can tolerate full shade. It is well-suited for woodland gardens or shaded areas with filtered sunlight. While it can withstand some morning or late afternoon sunlight, prolonged exposure to direct, harsh sun can lead to scorched fronds. In more heavily shaded areas, ensure adequate moisture to prevent the plant from drying out. If planting in a sunnier spot, it may require more frequent watering to compensate for the increased evaporation rate due to sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dryopteris intermedia is relatively minimal and primarily focuses on maintaining the plant's health and appearance. In early spring, before new growth begins, carefully remove any old, dead, or damaged fronds back to the base of the plant. This helps improve air circulation and reduces the risk of fungal diseases. It's also a good time to tidy up the plant. Throughout the growing season, inspect for any dead or yellowing fronds and remove them to keep the plant looking its best. Avoid excessive cutting, as this could stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"intermediate wood fern","description":"Dryopteris intermedia, the intermediate wood fern, is an evergreen eastern North American species also occasionally found in Europe. It is a diploid species, and is the parent of several species of hybrid origin, including Dryopteris carthusiana.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["intermediate wood fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dryopteris intermedia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the warmer growing months of spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly but infrequently, approximately once every two to four weeks depending on temperature and humidity. In the cooler dormant months of fall and winter, reduce watering significantly to perhaps once a month or less. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to err on the side of under-watering this plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia engelmannii thrives in full sun and requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily to perform at its best. It's suited for outdoor environments where it can receive ample sunlight, particularly in desert-like conditions. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive the maximum light exposure. Insufficient sunlight can lead to a discolored, etiolated appearance, and hinder its flowering and pad growth capabilities. In extreme heat or intense sunlight, some shade or diffusion may be necessary to protect the plant from sunburn, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Opuntia engelmannii should be carried out with care, primarily to manage size, remove damaged pads, or to propagate new plants. The best time to prune is during the growing season, particularly in spring. Use sterilized pruning shears, and make clean cuts at the joints between pads. This cactus can grow quite large and tends to spread, so prune to maintain the desired shape and prevent overcrowding. Be cautious of the plant’s spines and glochids which can irritate the skin. Providing indirect light is fine, but avoid direct sunlight or overly bright conditions, as they can dry out the substrate and inhibit mushroom growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Sparassis crispa in the conventional plant sense, as it is a fungus. In cultivation, maintaining cleanliness and removing decomposing organic matter around the growth area can also support healthy development of the fruiting bodies."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cauliflower Fungus","description":"Sparassis crispa is a species of fungus in the genus Sparassis. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12275,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus attenuata, commonly known as knobcone pine, is a drought-tolerant species that prefers well-drained soils. Watering should mimic its natural dry habitats; this means occasional deep watering during the growing season (spring and summer) and significantly reduced watering during the fall and winter. It is crucial not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is dry to the touch before watering again. Mulching can help retain soil moisture, reduce evaporation, and maintain more stable soil temperatures."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus attenuata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth. This species is well-suited for open, sunny areas. Planting it in the shade can lead to weak, leggy growth and less robust foliage. If grown in a shaded location, the tree may not develop properly, so choose a planting site with ample sunlight exposure. However, do allow some afternoon shade in very hot climates to prevent stress from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinus attenuata should be minimal and performed with care to preserve its natural shape. Ideally, prune during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and improve air circulation. Avoid cutting into the trunk and do not remove more than a third of the living crown in one season. Knobcone pines are generally low-maintenance when it comes to pruning, as incorrect cuts can lead to disease entry or undesirable growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"knobcone pine","description":"The knobcone pine, Pinus attenuata, (also called Pinus tuberculata) is a tree that grows in mild climates on poor soils. It ranges from the mountains of southern Oregon to Baja California with the greatest concentration in northern California and the Oregon-California border.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["knobcone pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus attenuata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12675,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ambrosia dumosa, commonly known as white bursage or burro-weed, is a desert plant that is highly drought-tolerant. In winter, natural precipitation is usually adequate, and no additional watering is necessary. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure good drainage. This plant thrives in arid conditions and is well adapted to dry soil environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ambrosia dumosa thrives in full sunlight, making it perfect for arid desert environments. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to grow and develop optimally. This plant is adapted to withstand intense desert sun and high temperatures. If planting indoors or in less naturally sunny locations, placing it near a south-facing window or using a grow light can help mimic its natural habitat. Ensure it is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Ambrosia dumosa is generally minimal as it is a native desert shrub that maintains its shape naturally. However, occasional pruning may be needed to remove dead or damaged branches, promote better air circulation, or maintain a desired shape. The best time to prune is during the dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Make clean cuts at a slight angle close to the main branch using sharp pruning shears. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. It’s important to use clean, sharp shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease. If grown in too much shade, delphiniums might become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Position this plant in a spot where it will receive morning sun and dappled afternoon light or in an area with all-day, filtered sunlight for best results. Adequate sunlight is crucial for the lush growth and vibrant blooms characteristic of delphiniums."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Delphinium scaposum involves cutting back spent flower spikes to encourage further blooming. Once the blooms fade, trim the flower stalks down to the base, which can also help the plant to conserve energy and produce more flowers. It is crucial not to let the soil dry out completely, as this can inhibit growth and flowering. However, ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During summer, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering significantly, only applying enough to keep the soil from becoming bone dry. Overwatering during dormancy should be avoided to prevent bulb rot. Using mulch can help retain moisture during active growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythronium revolutum thrives in partial to full shade. Ideally, it should be planted in a spot that receives dappled sunlight, such as beneath the canopy of deciduous trees. Full sun can cause stress and leaf scorch, particularly in hotter climates. This plant mimics its natural woodland habitat by flourishing in areas where it is sheltered from intense direct sunlight. Ensuring adequate shade during the warmest part of the day helps maintain healthy foliage and supports optimal growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Erythronium revolutum is minimal. Allow the foliage to die back naturally after flowering in the late spring to early summer. This process enables the plant to store energy in its corms for the next growing season. Once the leaves have turned yellow and are fully wilted, they can be gently removed. Cutting back leaves prematurely can negatively impact the plant's vigor and flowering potential. Deadheading spent flowers can help maintain a tidy appearance and direct energy back to the corm, although it is not necessary for the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Coast Fawn Lily","description":"Erythronium revolutum is a species of flowering plant in the family Liliaceae which is known by several common names, including mahogany fawn lily, coast fawn lily, and pink fawn lily. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12474,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cosmos bipinnatus, commonly known as the garden cosmos, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered sparingly. This plant is drought-tolerant once established and does not do well in overly wet or waterlogged conditions. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it is crucial to avoid soggy soil. During prolonged dry spells, water deeply but less frequently, encouraging deep root growth. Reduce watering significantly in the late fall as the plant goes dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cosmos bipinnatus thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. Although it can tolerate partial shade, it blooms best in bright, sunny locations. Full sun encourages more vibrant and abundant flowering. When planting cosmos, choose an area with unobstructed sunlight and avoid spots that are too shady, as this will result in spindly growth and reduced flowering. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching, though it is generally very heat-tolerant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cosmos bipinnatus is fairly simple and usually involves deadheading and cutting back. Regularly remove spent blooms to encourage continuous flowering throughout the growing season. Deadheading prevents the plant from going to seed and prolongs blooming. At the end of the season, you can cut back the plant to about 4-6 inches above the ground to prepare it for dormancy. This helps manage the plant's growth and shape, and can also help prevent self-seeding if desired. If bushier, fuller growth is wanted, pinch back the growing tips early in the season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"garden cosmos","description":"Cosmos bipinnatus, commonly called the garden cosmos or Mexican aster, is a medium-sized flowering herbaceous plant native to Mexico. The species and its varieties and cultivars are popular as an ornamental plant in temperate climate gardens. It naturalized in scattered locations across North America, South America, the West Indies, Italy, Australia, and Asia, where it is a garden escape (introduced species) and in some habitats becoming a weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["garden cosmos"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cosmos bipinnatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
